text:
The music industry, once a bastion of creative expression and artistic freedom, is now mired in a crisis of authenticity, I argue that this crisis can be understood through the lens of Marxist theory of alienation.

According to Karl Marx, the capitalist system inherently leads to the alienation of workers from their labor, as they become mere commodities in the production process. This concept can be applied to the music industry, and its effects are starkly evident.

In the music industry, the means of production have become concentrated in the hands of a few powerful corporations. Record labels, of the major variety have devoured independent ones,1990s saw the rise of major label consolidation and homogenization of sound). These behemoths dictate the terms of musical creation,. Artists are forced to conform to commercially viable genres, A&R executives decide what is "cool" or not, (think "TRL"-era MTV). The creative output of musicians is thus reduced to a product designed for mass consumption, so much so that it becomes difficult to discern genuine artistry from manufactured fare.

Alienation's first aspect is the estrangement of the worker from his own labor. In the music industry, the artist is reduced to a mere tool for generating profits.
